Problem 2

Prove Lemma 5.2.7. (Hint: use Lemma 5.2.5 frequently. For the Cauchy--Schwarz inequality, begin with the positivity property ⟨f,f⟩≥0\inner{f, f} \geq 0⟨f,f⟩≥0, but with fff replaced by the function f∥g∥22−⟨f,g⟩gf \norm{g}_2^2 - \inner{f, g}gf∥g∥22​−⟨f,g⟩g, and then simplify using Lemma 5.2.5. You may have to treat the case ∥g∥2=0\norm{g}_2 = 0∥g∥2​=0 separately. Use the Cauchy--Schwarz inequality to prove the triangle inequality.)

Lemma (5.2.7)

Let f,g∈C(R/Z;C)f, g \in C\p{\R/Z; \C}f,g∈C(R/Z;C).

  1. (Non-degeneracy) We have ∥f∥2=0\norm{f}_2 = 0∥f∥2​=0 if and only if f=0f = 0f=0.
  2. (Cauchy--Schwarz inequality) We have ∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥2∥g∥2\abs{\inner{f, g}} \leq \norm{f}_2 \norm{g}_2∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥2​∥g∥2​.
  3. (Triangle inequality) We have ∥f+g∥2≤∥f∥2+∥g∥2\norm{f + g}_2 \leq \norm{f}_2 + \norm{g}_2∥f+g∥2​≤∥f∥2​+∥g∥2​.
  4. (Pythagoras' theorem) If ⟨f,g⟩=0\inner{f, g} = 0⟨f,g⟩=0, then ∥f+g∥22=∥f∥22+∥g∥22\norm{f + g}_2^2 = \norm{f}_2^2 + \norm{g}_2^2∥f+g∥22​=∥f∥22​+∥g∥22​.
  5. (Homogeneity) We have ∥cf∥2=∣c∣∥f∥2\norm{cf}_2 = \abs{c} \norm{f}_2∥cf∥2​=∣c∣∥f∥2​ for all c∈Cc \in \Cc∈C.
Lemma (5.2.5)

Let f,g,h∈C(R/Z;C)f, g, h \in \C\p{\R/\Z; \C}f,g,h∈C(R/Z;C).

  1. (Hermitian property) We have ⟨g,f⟩=⟨f,g⟩‾\inner{g, f} = \conj{\inner{f, g}}⟨g,f⟩=⟨f,g⟩​.
  2. (Positivity) We have ⟨f,f⟩≥0\inner{f, f} \geq 0⟨f,f⟩≥0. Furthermore, we have ⟨f,f⟩=0\inner{f, f} = 0⟨f,f⟩=0 if and only if f=0f = 0f=0 (i.e., f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0 for all x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R).
  3. (Linearity in the first variable) We have ⟨f+g,h⟩=⟨f,h⟩+⟨g,h⟩\inner{f + g, h} = \inner{f, h} + \inner{g, h}⟨f+g,h⟩=⟨f,h⟩+⟨g,h⟩. For any complex number ccc, we have ⟨cf,g⟩=c⟨f,g⟩\inner{cf, g} = c\inner{f, g}⟨cf,g⟩=c⟨f,g⟩.
  4. (Antilinearity in the second variable) We have ⟨f,g+h⟩=⟨f,g⟩+⟨f,h⟩\inner{f, g + h} = \inner{f, g} + \inner{f, h}⟨f,g+h⟩=⟨f,g⟩+⟨f,h⟩. For any complex number ccc, we have ⟨f,cg⟩=c‾⟨f,g⟩\inner{f, cg} = \conj{c} \inner{f, g}⟨f,cg⟩=c⟨f,g⟩.
Solution.

  1. At this stage, we have already proven that ⟨−,−⟩\inner{-, -}⟨−,−⟩ is an inner product. Thus, ∥f∥2=0  ⟺  ⟨f,f⟩=0  ⟺  f=0\norm{f}_2 = 0 \iff \inner{f, f} = 0 \iff f = 0∥f∥2​=0⟺⟨f,f⟩=0⟺f=0.

  2. Following the hint,

    0≤⟨f∥g∥22−⟨f,g⟩g,f∥g∥22−⟨f,g⟩g⟩=∥f∥22∥g∥24+∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22−∥g∥22⟨f,g⟩‾⟨f,g⟩−∥g∥22⟨f,g⟩⟨f,g⟩‾=∥f∥22∥g∥24−∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22.\begin{aligned} 0 &\leq \inner{f \norm{g}_2^2 - \inner{f, g}g, f \norm{g}_2^2 - \inner{f, g}g} \\ &= \norm{f}_2^2 \norm{g}_2^4 + \abs{\inner{f, g}}^2 \norm{g}_2^2 - \norm{g}_2^2 \conj{\inner{f, g}} \inner{f, g} - \norm{g}_2^2 \inner{f, g} \conj{\inner{f, g}} \\ &= \norm{f}_2^2 \norm{g}_2^4 - \abs{\inner{f, g}}^2 \norm{g}_2^2. \end{aligned}0​≤⟨f∥g∥22​−⟨f,g⟩g,f∥g∥22​−⟨f,g⟩g⟩=∥f∥22​∥g∥24​+∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22​−∥g∥22​⟨f,g⟩​⟨f,g⟩−∥g∥22​⟨f,g⟩⟨f,g⟩​=∥f∥22​∥g∥24​−∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22​.​

    Rearranging, we get

    ∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22≤∥f∥22∥g∥24.\abs{\inner{f, g}}^2 \norm{g}_2^2 \leq \norm{f}_2^2 \norm{g}_2^4.∣⟨f,g⟩∣2∥g∥22​≤∥f∥22​∥g∥24​.

    if ∥g∥2=0\norm{g}_2 = 0∥g∥2​=0, then g=0g = 0g=0 and the Cauchy--Schwarz inequality is trivial. Otherwise, we may divide through by ∥g∥22\norm{g}_2^2∥g∥22​ and take square roots to get

    ∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥2∥g∥2.\abs{\inner{f, g}} \leq \norm{f}_2 \norm{g}_2.∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥2​∥g∥2​.

  3. We square both sides, apply the triangle inequality (for complex numbers), and Cauchy--Schwarz, which give

    ∥f+g∥22≤∥f∥22+∥g∥22+2∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥22+∥g∥22+2∥f∥2∥g∥2=(∥f∥2+∥g∥2)2.\norm{f + g}_2^2 \leq \norm{f}_2^2 + \norm{g}_2^2 + 2\abs{\inner{f, g}} \leq \norm{f}_2^2 + \norm{g}_2^2 + 2\norm{f}_2\norm{g}_2 = \p{\norm{f}_2 + \norm{g}_2}^2.∥f+g∥22​≤∥f∥22​+∥g∥22​+2∣⟨f,g⟩∣≤∥f∥22​+∥g∥22​+2∥f∥2​∥g∥2​=(∥f∥2​+∥g∥2​)2.

    Taking square roots gives the triangle inequality.

  4. Note that if ⟨f,g⟩=0\inner{f, g} = 0⟨f,g⟩=0, then ⟨g,f⟩=⟨f,g⟩‾=0\inner{g, f} = \conj{\inner{f, g}} = 0⟨g,f⟩=⟨f,g⟩​=0. Thus,

    ∥f+g∥22=∥f∥22+∥g∥22+⟨f,g⟩+⟨g,f⟩=∥f∥22+∥g∥22.\norm{f + g}_2^2 = \norm{f}_2^2 + \norm{g}_2^2 + \inner{f, g} + \inner{g, f} = \norm{f}_2^2 + \norm{g}_2^2.∥f+g∥22​=∥f∥22​+∥g∥22​+⟨f,g⟩+⟨g,f⟩=∥f∥22​+∥g∥22​.

  5. We have

    ∥cf∥=⟨cf,cf⟩=∣c∣2⟨f,f⟩=∣c∣2∥f∥22.\norm{cf} = \inner{cf, cf} = \abs{c}^2 \inner{f, f} = \abs{c}^2 \norm{f}_2^2.∥cf∥=⟨cf,cf⟩=∣c∣2⟨f,f⟩=∣c∣2∥f∥22​.

    Taking square roots gives the identity.

Problem 6

Prove Corollary 5.3.6. (Hint: use Lemma 5.3.5. For the second identity, either use Pythagoras’ theorem and induction, or substitute f=∑n=−NNcnenf = \sum_{n=-N}^N c_n e_nf=∑n=−NN​cn​en​ and expand everything out.)

Corollary (5.3.6)

Let f=∑n=−NNcnenf = \sum_{n=-N}^N c_n e_nf=∑n=−NN​cn​en​ be a trigonometric polynomial. Then we have the formula

cn=⟨f,en⟩c_n = \inner{f, e_n}cn​=⟨f,en​⟩

for all integers −N≤n≤N-N \leq n \leq N−N≤n≤N. Also, we have 0=⟨f,en⟩0 = \inner{f, e_n}0=⟨f,en​⟩ whenever n>Nn > Nn>N or n<−Nn < -Nn<−N. Also, we have the identity

∥f∥22=∑n=−NN∣cn∣2.\norm{f}_2^2 = \sum_{n=-N}^N \abs{c_n}^2.∥f∥22​=n=−N∑N​∣cn​∣2.

⟨f,en⟩=∑m=−NNcm⟨en,em⟩=cn.\inner{f, e_n} = \sum_{m=-N}^N c_m \inner{e_n, e_m} = c_n.⟨f,en​⟩=m=−N∑N​cm​⟨en​,em​⟩=cn​.

If n∉[−N,N]n \notin \br{-N, N}n∈/[−N,N], then for all n≠mn \neq mn=m for all m∈[−N,N]m \in \br{-N, N}m∈[−N,N], so

⟨f,en⟩=∑m=−NNcm⟨en,em⟩=∑m=−NN0=0.\inner{f, e_n} = \sum_{m=-N}^N c_m \inner{e_n, e_m} = \sum_{m=-N}^N 0 = 0.⟨f,en​⟩=m=−N∑N​cm​⟨en​,em​⟩=m=−N∑N​0=0.

Finally,

∥f∥22=⟨∑n=−NNcnen,∑m=−NNcmem⟩=∑n=−NN∑m=−NNcncm‾⟨en,em⟩=∑n=−NNcncn‾=∑n=−NN∣cn∣2.\begin{aligned} \norm{f}_2^2 &= \inner{\sum_{n=-N}^N c_ne_n, \sum_{m=-N}^N c_me_m} \\ &= \sum_{n=-N}^N \sum_{m=-N}^N c_n \conj{c_m} \inner{e_n, e_m} \\ &= \sum_{n=-N}^N c_n \conj{c_n} \\ &= \sum_{n=-N}^N \abs{c_n}^2. \end{aligned}∥f∥22​​=⟨n=−N∑N​cn​en​,m=−N∑N​cm​em​⟩=n=−N∑N​m=−N∑N​cn​cm​​⟨en​,em​⟩=n=−N∑N​cn​cn​​=n=−N∑N​∣cn​∣2.​

Problem 7

Prove Lemma 5.4.4. (Hint: to prove that f∗gf * gf∗g is continuous, you will have to do something like use the fact that fff is bounded, and ggg is uniformly continuous, or vice versa. To prove that f∗g=g∗ff*g = g*ff∗g=g∗f, you will need to use the periodicity to "cut and paste" the interval [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1].)

Lemma (5.4.4)

Let f,g,h∈C(R/Z;C)f, g, h \in C\p{\R/\Z; \C}f,g,h∈C(R/Z;C).

  1. (Closure) The convolution f∗gf * gf∗g is continuous and Z\ZZ-periodic. In other words, f∗g∈C(R/Z;C)f * g \in C\p{\R/Z; \C}f∗g∈C(R/Z;C).
  2. (Commutativity) We have f∗g=g∗ff * g = g * ff∗g=g∗f.
  3. (Bilinearity) We have f∗(g+h)=f∗g+f∗hf * \p{g + h} = f*g + f*hf∗(g+h)=f∗g+f∗h and (f+g)∗h=f∗h+g∗h\p{f + g} * h = f*h + g*h(f+g)∗h=f∗h+g∗h. For any complex number ccc, we have c(f∗g)=(cf)∗g=f∗(cg)c\p{f*g} = \p{cf}*g = f*\p{cg}c(f∗g)=(cf)∗g=f∗(cg).
Solution.

  1. If ∥f∥∞=0\norm{f}_\infty = 0∥f∥∞​=0, then f∗g=0∈C(R/Z;C)f * g = 0 \in C\p{\R/\Z; \C}f∗g=0∈C(R/Z;C). Otherwise, since g∈C(R/Z;C)g \in C\p{\R/\Z; \C}g∈C(R/Z;C), it is uniformly continuous, so given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that

    ∣z−z′∣<δ  ⟹  ∣g(z)−g(z′)∣<ε∥f∥∞.\abs{z - z'} < \delta \implies \abs{g\p{z} - g\p{z'}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{\norm{f}_\infty}.∣z−z′∣<δ⟹∣g(z)−g(z′)∣<∥f∥∞​ε​.

    Assume ∣x−x′∣<δ\abs{x - x'} < \delta∣x−x′∣<δ. Then for any y∈[0,1]y \in \br{0, 1}y∈[0,1], we have ∣(x−y)−(x′−y)∣=∣x−x′∣<δ\abs{\p{x - y} - \p{x' - y}} = \abs{x - x'} < \delta∣(x−y)−(x′−y)∣=∣x−x′∣<δ, and so

    ∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣≤∫01∣f(y)∣∣g(x−y)−g(x′−y)∣ dy<∫01∥f∥∞⋅ε∥f∥∞ dy=ε.\begin{aligned} \abs{\p{f * g}\p{x} - \p{f * g}\p{x'}} &\leq \int_0^1 \abs{f\p{y}} \abs{g\p{x - y} - g\p{x' - y}} \,\diff{y} \\ &< \int_0^1 \norm{f}_\infty \cdot \frac{\varepsilon}{\norm{f}_\infty} \,\diff{y} \\ &= \varepsilon. \end{aligned}∣(f∗g)(x)−(f∗g)(x′)∣​≤∫01​∣f(y)∣∣g(x−y)−g(x′−y)∣dy<∫01​∥f∥∞​⋅∥f∥∞​ε​dy=ε.​

    This shows that f∗gf * gf∗g is continuous. To show Z\ZZ-periodicity,

    (f∗g)(x+1)=∫01f(y)g(x+1−y) dy=∫01f(y)g(x−y) dy=(f∗g)(x)\p{f * g}\p{x + 1} = \int_0^1 f\p{y}g\p{x + 1 - y} \,\diff{y} = \int_0^1 f\p{y}g\p{x - y} \,\diff{y} = \p{f * g}\p{x}(f∗g)(x+1)=∫01​f(y)g(x+1−y)dy=∫01​f(y)g(x−y)dy=(f∗g)(x)

    by Z\ZZ-periodicity of ggg.

  2. First, for any h∈C(R/Z;C)h \in C\p{\R/\Z; \C}h∈C(R/Z;C) and k∈Zk \in \Zk∈Z, the substitution u=y+ku = y + ku=y+k gives

    ∫abh(y) dy=∫a+kb+kh(u−k) du=∫a+kb+kh(y) dy.(∗)\int_a^b h\p{y} \,\diff{y} = \int_{a+k}^{b+k} h\p{u - k} \,\diff{u} = \int_{a+k}^{b+k} h\p{y} \,\diff{y}. \tag{$*$}∫ab​h(y)dy=∫a+kb+k​h(u−k)du=∫a+kb+k​h(y)dy.(∗)

    (In the last line, uuu is a dummy variable, so I can swap it for any symbol I like.)

    In the following computation, we let k=⌊x⌋k = \lfloor x \rfloork=⌊x⌋ and use the substitution u=x−yu = x - yu=x−y.

    (f∗g)(x)=∫01f(y)g(x−y) dy=−∫xx−1f(x−u)g(u) du=∫x−1xg(u)f(x−u) du=∫x−1kg(u)f(x−u) du+∫kxg(u)f(x−u) du.\begin{aligned} \p{f * g}\p{x} &= \int_0^1 f\p{y} g\p{x - y} \,\diff{y} \\ &= -\int_x^{x-1} f\p{x - u} g\p{u} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \int_{x-1}^x g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \int_{x-1}^k g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} + \int_k^x g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u}. \end{aligned}(f∗g)(x)​=∫01​f(y)g(x−y)dy=−∫xx−1​f(x−u)g(u)du=∫x−1x​g(u)f(x−u)du=∫x−1k​g(u)f(x−u)du+∫kx​g(u)f(x−u)du.​

    By (∗*∗) above, ∫kxg(u)f(x−u) du=∫k−1x−1g(u)f(x−u) du\int_k^x g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} = \int_{k-1}^{x-1} g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u}∫kx​g(u)f(x−u)du=∫k−1x−1​g(u)f(x−u)du, so by (∗*∗) again,

    (f∗g)(x)=∫x−1kg(u)f(x−u) du+∫k−1x−1g(u)f(x−u) du=∫k−1kg(u)f(x−u) du=∫01g(u)f(x−u) du=(g∗f)(x).\begin{aligned} \p{f * g}\p{x} &= \int_{x-1}^k g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} + \int_{k-1}^{x-1} g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \int_{k-1}^k g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \int_0^1 g\p{u} f\p{x - u} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \p{g * f}\p{x}. \end{aligned}(f∗g)(x)​=∫x−1k​g(u)f(x−u)du+∫k−1x−1​g(u)f(x−u)du=∫k−1k​g(u)f(x−u)du=∫01​g(u)f(x−u)du=(g∗f)(x).​

  3. Since convolution is commutative, it suffices to show that it is linear in the first component. By linearity of the Riemann integral,

    [(f+cg)∗h](x)=∫01(f+cg)(y)h(x−y) dy=∫01f(y)h(x−y) dy+c∫01g(y)h(x−y) dy=(f∗h)(x)+c(g∗h)(x).\begin{aligned} \br{\p{f + cg} * h}\p{x} &= \int_0^1 \p{f + cg}\p{y} h\p{x - y} \,\diff{y} \\ &= \int_0^1 f\p{y} h\p{x - y} \,\diff{y} + c\int_0^1 g\p{y} h\p{x - y} \,\diff{y} \\ &= \p{f * h}\p{x} + c\p{g * h}\p{x}. \end{aligned}[(f+cg)∗h](x)​=∫01​(f+cg)(y)h(x−y)dy=∫01​f(y)h(x−y)dy+c∫01​g(y)h(x−y)dy=(f∗h)(x)+c(g∗h)(x).​

    Plugging in f=0f = 0f=0 gives homogeneity, and c=1c = 1c=1 gives additivity.
